timeline.bodyText: Is there are more appropriate annotation to use here? Perhaps just "Component"? If that has the same effect, I think that'd be better because this class of course is not a controller.
timeline.author: rjrudin

replies.bodyText: Actually, i think the handler should be a controller. It can be refactor into the com.marklogic.hub.oneui.controllers package to make it more clear.
replies.author: hao1st

replies.bodyText: I agree with @rjrudin . I think it should be a "Component" and not a "Controller".
replies.author: srinathgit

replies.bodyText: OK, i do not have strong opinion with which one we should use for the spring annotation. I will check it because of majority takes over.
replies.author: hao1st

timeline.bodyText:
There needs to be a test for this method. Otherwise, someone could add code that causes a null pointer exception or something similar, and we'd never know it.
I think a suitable test would be to populate that map with two DatabaseClient objects, and then call destroy. Then verify that the map is empty (I can't think of a good way to verify that the clients were released). That's a decent smoke test.
timeline.author: rjrudin

replies.bodyText: @rjrudin A new test class was created for checking the function.
replies.author: hao1st

replies.bodyText: Just a note - this logic is the sort of thing that should eventually move into a HubClient class, where it'd be a lot easier to test - i.e. create a HubClient with 3 DatabaseClients, then call destroy, then verify that each of the 3 DatabaseClients throws an error if you try to do something with it.
